{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Rape}} {{Violence against women}} '''Corrective rape''' is a [[hate crime]] in which one or more people are [[rape]]d because of their perceived [[sexual orientation]] or [[gender identity]]. The common intended consequence of the rape, as seen by the perpetrator, is to turn the person [[heterosexuality|heterosexual]] or to enforce conformity with [[gender stereotypes]].<ref name="Bartle" /><ref name="academia.edu">Baghdadi 2013, https://www.academia.edu/9634350/Corrective_Rape_of_black_lesbian_women_in_Post-Apartheid_South_Africa_investigating_the_symbolic_violence_and_resulting_misappropriation_of_symbolic_power_that_ensues_within_a_nexus_of_social_imaginaries</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Diversity and|last=Thompson|first=Sherwood|publisher=Roman & Littlefield|year=2015|isbn=|location=Lanham, MD|pages=475}}</ref>
The term ''corrective rape'' was coined in South Africa after well-known cases of corrective rapes of [[lesbian]]s such as [[Eudy Simelane]] (who was also murdered in the same attack) and Zoliswa Nkonyana became public. Although some countries have laws protecting [[LGBT]] people, corrective rape is often overlooked.<ref name="Hawthorne" /><ref name="Di" />
== Definitions== Corrective rape is the use of [[rape]] against people who do not conform to perceived [[Norm (social)|social norms]] regarding [[human sexuality]] or [[gender role]]s. The goal is to punish perceived abnormal behavior and reinforce societal norms.<ref name="Actionaid" /><ref>Baghdadi 2013,https://www.academia.edu/9634350/Corrective_Rape_of_black_lesbian_women_in_Post-Apartheid_South_Africa_investigating_the_symbolic_violence_and_resulting_misappropriation_of_symbolic_power_that_ensues_within_a_nexus_of_social_imaginaries</ref> The crime was first identified in South Africa,<ref name="Janoff" /> where it is sometimes supervised by members of the woman's family or local community.<ref name="Bartle" />
The [[United Nations]] [[UNAIDS]] 2015 Terminology Guidelines suggests that use of the term ''corrective rape'' should no longer be used, as it gives off the perception that something needs to be fixed. The guidelines propose that the term ''[[homophobic]] rape'' should be used instead.<ref>{{cite web|last1=United Nations|title=UNAIDS 2015 Terminology Guidelines|url=http://www.unaids.org/sites/default/files/media_asset/2015_terminology_guidelines_en.pdf|website=UNAIDS.org|accessdate=21 November 2015}}</ref>
==Contributing factors and motivations== Corrective rape is a [[hate crime]].<ref name=":1" /> However, due to [[homophobia]] and [[heteronormativity]], hate crimes based on sexuality (as opposed to race, gender, class, age, etc.) are often not recognized by authorities.<ref name=":4" /> A 2000 study suggested an atmosphere supportive of hate crimes against gay men and lesbians, reactions to hate crimes by the broader community, and responses by police and justice systems contribute to corrective rape.<ref name="Bartle" />
Some people believe corrective rape can fix people who do not conform to gender norms or who are not heterosexual. [[ActionAid]] reports that survivors remember being told that they were being taught a lesson.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.actionaid.org.uk/sites/default/files/publications/hate_crimes_the_rise_of_corrective_rape_in_south_africa_september_2009.pdf|title=ActionAid|last=|first=|date=2009 |publisher=ActionAid|access-date=2016-04-20}}</ref>
Some sources argue that many cases of corrective rape are caused by [[is–ought problem|drawing moral conclusions]] from the [[nature–nurture debate]]. Despite the scientific community believing that sexual orientation is the result of biology and environment,<ref name="pediatrics2004">{{cite journal |doi=10.1542/peds.113.6.1827 |author=Frankowski BL|author2=American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on Adolescence|title=Sexual orientation and adolescents |journal=[[Pediatrics (journal)|Pediatrics]]|volume=113 |issue=6 |pages=1827–32 |date=June 2004|pmid=15173519|url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/113/6/1827.long}}</ref><ref name="Lamanna">{{cite book|authors=Mary Ann Lamanna, Agnes Riedmann, Susan D Stewart|title=Marriages, Families, and Relationships: Making Choices in a Diverse Society|publisher=[[Cengage Learning]]|isbn=1305176898|year=2014|page=82|accessdate=February 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fofaAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA82|quote=The reason some individuals develop a gay sexual identity has not been definitively established  – nor do we yet understand the development of heterosexuality. The American Psychological Association (APA) takes the position that a variety of factors impact a person's sexuality. The most recent literature from the APA says that sexual orientation is not a choice that can be changed at will, and that sexual orientation is most likely the result of a complex interaction of environmental, cognitive and biological factors...is shaped at an early age...[and evidence suggests] biological, including genetic or inborn hormonal factors, play a significant role in a person's sexuality (American Psychological Association 2010).}}</ref><ref name="Stuart">{{cite book|author=Gail Wiscarz Stuart|title=Principles and Practice of Psychiatric Nursing|publisher=[[Elsevier Health Sciences]]|isbn=032329412X|year=2014|page=502|accessdate=February 11, 2016|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ivALBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA502|quote=No conclusive evidence supports any one specific cause of homosexuality; however, most researchers agree that biological and social factors influence the development of sexual orientation.}}</ref> many people do not believe that homosexuality (or other forms of non-heterosexuality) has a genetic basis and instead believe it is only the result of one's environment. Because of this, some of these people believe sexual orientation can be changed, or in this case, fixed.<ref>McCommon B (2006). "Antipsychiatry and the Gay Rights Movement". Psychiatr Serv 57 (12): 1809. doi:10.1176/appi.ps.57.12.1809</ref><ref>Rissmiller DJ, Rissmiller J; Rissmiller (2006). "Letter in reply". Psychiatr Serv 57 (12): 1809–1810. doi:10.1176/appi.ps.57.12.1809-a</ref><ref>Ladie Terry. (1994) 'ORPHANS' SPEAK OUT. San Jose Mercury News (California) Tuesday MORNING FINAL EDITION. December 13, 1994</ref>
== Intersectionality == [[Intersectionality]] is ''intersecting'' social identities and related systems of [[oppression]], [[Dominance hierarchy|domination]], or [[discrimination]]. In South Africa, black lesbians face homophobia, [[sexism]], [[racism]], and [[classism]]. Research in 2008 by Triangle, a gay rights group, revealed that black lesbians were twice as afraid of sexual assault compared to white lesbians.<ref name=":0" /> In addition, black women who identify as lesbians are seen as "un-African" by their peers.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=3d95b04c-aa02-4955-8d90-80637d88d9e2%2540sessionmgr104&vid=7&hid=108|title=EBSCO Publishing Service Selection Page|website=eds.b.ebscohost.com|access-date=2016-05-02}}</ref> Taking into account race and sexuality together is essential when examining corrective rape, as both subjects cross into each other and influence each other heavily.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=Feb 2013|title=Rape as a Weapon of Hate: Discursive Constructions and Material Consequences of Black Lesbianism in South Africa|url=|journal=Women's Studies in Communication|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref>
Intersectionality plays a major role in corrective rape cases, as many occur in underdeveloped countries such as South Africa and India in which race, class, and gender are factors in the rights an individual will receive. Sexuality and gender especially, define the social and political rank of victims. Many are ostracized, and other abusive measures are taken in order to cure individuals of their sexuality.
== Impact on victims == Corrective rape and other accompanying acts of violence can result in [[physical trauma|physical]] and [[psychological trauma]], mutilation, unwanted [[pregnancy]], and may contribute to [[suicide]].<ref name="Hawthorne" /><ref name="Actionaid" /><ref name="Mabuse" /> Corrective rape is a major contributor to [[HIV]] infection in South African lesbians.<ref name="Actionaid" /> In South Africa approximately 10% of lesbians are HIV positive, with corrective rape being the most likely cause.<ref name=":3" /> HIV in South Africa is pandemic, and due to homophobia there is a lack of education about sexually transmitted diseases among lesbians. Homophobic laws and discrimination in South Africa contribute to the poor quality of health care for minorities.
The psychological effects of corrective rape on victims can be detrimental. Many victims in countries such as South Africa and India where corrective rape is most prevalent suffer from a strong sense of insecurity and disempowerment due to strong homophobia in their communities. This homophobia can lead to both physical and psychological violence. There have been 30 lesbians who have been murdered in South Africa in the last 15 years because of their sexual orientation. However, violence against the LGBTQ community in South Africa is seldom reported.<ref name=":2" /> Survivors of corrective rape suffer from triple discrimination for being a female, black, and homosexual.<ref name=":2" /> This is especially true in South African townships, where corrective rape is common for lesbian women.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nduna|first=Mzikazi|date=2012|title=Disempowerment And Psychological Distress In The Lives Of Young People In Eastern Cape, South Africa|url=|journal=Journal of Child and Family Studies|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Corrective rape victims may suffer from [[depression (mood)|depression]], [[Anxiety disorder|anxiety]], and/or [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress disorder]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=du Toit|first=Louise|date=2014|title=Shifting Meanings of Postconflict Sexual Violence in South Africa|url=|journal=Signs: Journal of Women In Culture and Society|doi=|pmid=|access-date=}}</ref> Due to racial and sexual discrimination in health care, victims must often deal with these issues on their own.<ref name=":2" />
== Prevalence == Corrective rape has been reported in [[Thailand]],<ref name="Mieses" /> [[Zimbabwe]],<ref name="Shaw" /><ref name="UN" /> [[Ecuador]],<ref name="Caselli" /> [[Uganda]],<ref name="GuarUganda"/> [[South Africa]],<ref name="Middleton" /> and [[India]].
=== India === Children in India have been speaking out about how their parents are sanctioning the child's sexuality by using Corrective Rape Therapy (same as Corrective Rape).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/life-style/relationships/parenting/Victims-of-corrective-rape-speak-up/articleshow/47602170.cm|title=Victims of Corrective Rape Speak Up|date=June 2015|work=Times of India|access-date=|via=}}</ref> Corrective Rape in India typically happens in order to protect the family name, to avoid shaming from religious communities, and to prevent abnormal perception by the surrounding community. In India, there is a general discomfort with discussing homosexuality, even if an individual identifies as homosexual. This discomfort comes from the overall negative attitude towards homosexuality and the fact is that individuals in India who identify as homosexual are victimized at a higher rate. There is also a high level of negativity towards the trans community in India. Religious commitments tend to be very strong in traditional cultures and this is where much of the tension and poor perception came from. According to statistics with the Crisis Intervention Team of LGBT Collective in Telangana, India, there have been 15 reported instances of corrective rape that have been reported in the last 5 years.<ref>{{Cite news|title=India's Bollywood Speaks Out Against Rape|last=MM Vetticad|first=Anna|date=10 July 2014|work=Newspaper|via=}}</ref> In general, there has been a 902 percent increase in reported rapes in India from 1971 to 2012; however, it is estimated that 90 percent of sex crimes in the country go unreported.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/07/india-bollywood-speaks-out-against-rape-201471075423510320.html|title=India's Bollywood speaks out against rape|website=www.aljazeera.com|access-date=2016-05-04}}</ref>
=== Zimbabwe === {{Further information|LGBT rights in Zimbabwe}}
A U.S. State Department report on Zimbabwe states, "In response to social pressure, some families reportedly subjected their LGBT members to corrective rape and forced marriages to encourage heterosexual conduct. Such crimes were rarely reported to police. Women, in particular, were subjected to rape by male family members."<ref name="USZimbabwe2012"/> Following the publication of an earlier report with similar wording,<ref name="USZimbabwe2009"/> Zimbabwean journalist [[Angus Shaw (writer)|Angus Shaw]] said that lesbian women are raped by men to make them enjoy heterosexual acts and gay men are raped by women to remove their sexual orientation tendencies.<ref name="Gonda"/>
=== South Africa === {{Further information|LGBT rights in South Africa|Rape in South Africa}} [[File:Justice For Sizakhele & Salome (8036300204).jpg|thumb|Soweto Pride 2012 participants remember two lesbians who were raped and murdered in 2007.<ref name="Ndaba">{{cite web|last=Ndaba|first=Baldwin|title='Hate crime' against lesbians slated|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/hate-crime-against-lesbians-slated-1.361821#.Urb7Pxb78y4|publisher=IOL News|accessdate=22 December 2013|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6QiX1JhnL|archivedate=30 June 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>]] In South Africa, women have less sexual and economic power than men.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mantell|first1=Joanne|last2=Needham|first2=Sarah|last3=Smit|first3=Jennifer Ann|last4=Hoffman|first4=Susie|last5=Cebekhulu|first5=Queen|last6=Adams-Skinner|first6=Jessica|last7=Exner|first7=Theresa|last8=Mabude|first8=Zonke|last9=Beksinska|first9=Mags|last10=Stein|first10=Zena|last11=Milford|first11=Cecilia|title=Gender norms in South Africa: implications for HIV and pregnancy prevention among African and Indian women students at a South African tertiary institution|journal=Culture, Health & Sexuality|date=February 2009|volume=11|issue=2|pages=139–157|doi=10.1080/13691050802521155|pmc=2782559|pmid=19247859}}</ref> One of the factors associated with this inequality is strict gender roles, which has led to one of the highest rates of [[violence against women]] in the world.<ref name="Mieses" /><ref name="HRW" /> The South African government conducted a survey in 2009 on sexual assault. One in four men admit to having sex with a woman who did not consent and nearly half of these men admitted to raping more than once.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carter|first1=Clare|title=The Brutality of "Corrective Rape" |url=http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2013/07/26/opinion/26corrective-rape.html?_r=0|website=nytimes.com|accessdate=12 June 2014}}</ref> It is also estimated that a woman is raped every 26 seconds in South Africa.<ref name=":0" /> Corrective rape is used as a punishment for people who are gay or do not fit traditional gender roles (usually women), where often they are [[verbally abused]] before the rape. The perpetrator may claim to be teaching [the women] a lesson on how to be a "real woman".<ref name="academia.edu"/> Because women have less control over their [[economics]], which creates economic vulnerability, they have less control over their own sexual activities.<ref name="Mieses" /> Poor black women who live in townships are more likely to become victims of corrective violence, and gay women are more likely to be isolated with little support, which increases their chances of being targeted.<ref name="Di" /><ref name="Mabuse" />
The [[South African Constitution]] is one of the most progressive constitutions in the world. It states that no person shall be discriminated against based on his or her gender, [[race (human categorization)|race]], or sexual orientation.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="Mieses" /><ref name="CNN" /> [[Equality Act (South Africa)|The Equality Act]] of 2000 specifically bans [[hate crime]]s, crimes in which people are targeted because of one or more aspects of their identity.<ref name=":0" /> Although this technically includes crimes based on sexual orientation, in practice such cases are not brought to trial.<ref name=":0" /> Crimes based on sexual orientation are not expressly recognized in South Africa; corrective rape reports are not separated from general rape reports.<ref name="Di" /><ref name="Mabuse" /> In December 2009, there had been 31 recorded murders of lesbians in South Africa since 1998, but only one had resulted in a conviction.<ref name="Mieses" />
The reason for this discrepancy between the law and practice is a result of [[heteronormativity]] and homophobia in South Africa. Heteronormativity can be defined as "the institutions, structures of understanding, and practical orientations that make heterosexuality not only seem coherent--that is organised as a sexuality--but also privileged."<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://eds.b.ebscohost.com/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?sid=7107cbc9-729a-47b1-995e-a1608ec7c9aa%2540sessionmgr115&vid=2&hid=108|title=EBSCO Publishing Service Selection Page|website=eds.b.ebscohost.com|access-date=2016-05-02}}</ref> Some historians believe the heteronormativity in South Africa can be attributed to the nation's postcolonial years of racism, and it appears that today many South Africans are recommitted to their traditional heritage.<ref name=":2" /> Black South African lesbians are not included in this [[social construction]], and this leads back to the concept of [[intersectionality]]. Black lesbians in South Africa are not only excluded because of their sexual orientation but also because of their ethnicity. As displayed in the media, most homosexuality is displayed as white, leaving black lesbians in South African even more marginalized.<ref name=":2" /> In South Africa, homosexuality is regarded as "un-African" by some.<ref name=":1" /> In 2004, the [[Human Sciences Research Council (South Africa)|Human Science Research Council]] found that 78% of the respondents thought of homosexuality as unacceptable. According to [[Human Rights Watch]], in the last 20 years, attitudes toward [[homosexuality]] have become worse in South Africa.<ref name="Hazelton" />
Corrective rape is on the rise in South Africa. More than 10 lesbians are raped weekly to correct their sexual preferences, as estimated by Luleki Sizwe, a South African nonprofit.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="Contemporary Sexuality" /> It is estimated that at least 500 lesbians become victims of corrective rape every year and that 86% of black lesbians in the [[Western Cape]] live in fear of being [[sexually assaulted]], as reported by the Triangle Project in 2008.<ref name="Di" /> Yet victims of corrective rape are less likely to report it because of the negative social view of homosexuality.<ref name="Di" /> Under-reporting is high for sexually violent crimes, thus the number of corrective rapes are likely higher than what is reported.<ref name="Di" />
Although it is thought to be uncommon, men also become victims of corrective rape. A study conducted by OUT [[LGBT]] Well-being and the University of South Africa Centre for Applied Psychology (UCAP) showed that "the percentage of black gay men who said they have experienced corrective rape matched that of the black lesbians who partook in the study".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Louw|first1=Angelo|title=Men are also 'corrective rape' victims |url=http://mg.co.za/article/2014-04-11-men-are-also-corrective-rape-victims|website=Mail&Guardian |accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> However, not all men admit to being victims of corrective rape.
One South African man stated, "Lesbians get raped and killed because it is accepted by our community and by our culture."<ref name="Middleton" /> Kekelesto explained that her experience as, "where men try to turn you into a real African woman" and that she was being taught how to be a black woman.<ref name="academia.edu" /> [[File:Dying For Justice (8036294736).jpg|thumb|left|Soweto Pride 2012 participants protest against violence against lesbians with a "Dying for Justice" banner and T-shirts which read "Solidarity with women who speak out".]]
Galip Asvat, a successful hair salon business owner, is a gay man born in [[Klerksdorp]]. He moved to [[Hillbrow]], which was a haven for the LGBT community, in the early 2000s.<ref name="mg.co.za">{{cite web|last1=Louw|first1=Angelo|title=Men are also 'corrective rape' victims|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2014-04-11-men-are-also-corrective-rape-victims|website=Mail&Guardian|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> One early morning in 2007, Asvat was ambushed and raped by three men in his apartment building. On his attack, he said, "They thought I was a woman, and when they found out I was a man, that's when they became even more violent."<ref name="mg.co.za"/> His beating was brutal and the gang of men nearly cut off his genitals.
Sizakele Sigasa, a lesbian activist living in [[Soweto]], and her partner Salome Masooa were raped, [[torture]]d, and murdered in July 2007. South African lesbian-[[gay rights]] organizations, including the umbrella-group Joint Working Group, said the attack was driven by lesbophobia.<ref name="Ndaba"/> Two other rape/murders of lesbians occurred in South Africa earlier in Summer 2007: Simangele Nhlapo, member of an [[HIV-positive]] support group was raped and murdered in June, along with her two-year-old daughter; and Madoe Mafubedu, age 16, was raped and stabbed to death.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pithouse|first=Richard|title=Only Protected on Paper|url=http://sacsis.org.za/site/article/644.1|publisher=The South African Civil Society Information Service|accessdate=22 December 2013|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6QiX79Fi5|archivedate=30 June 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
On 28 April 2008, 31-year-old soccer player [[Eudy Simelane]] was abducted, gang-raped and killed in [[KwaThema]], her hometown near Johannesburg.<ref name="HRW" /><ref name="Kelly" /> Simelane was a star of the South Africa’s acclaimed [[Banyana Banyana]] national female football squad, an avid equality rights campaigner, and one of the first women to live openly as a lesbian in KwaThema.<ref name="Kelly" />
On 24 April 2011, LGBT activist [[Noxolo Nogwaza]] was raped and murdered in KwaThema.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13265300 |title=South Africa killing of lesbian Nogwaza 'a hate crime' |date=3 May 2011 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=28 November 2012 |archivedate=28 November 2012 |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6CXiYuzvx |deadurl=no}}</ref>
In 2013, two writers from South African men's magazine ''[[FHM]]'' were fired as a result of corrective rape jokes they made on Facebook. After a disciplinary hearing on Friday, July 19, 2013, ''FHM'' dismissed both men from their positions, calling their comments "entirely unacceptable".<ref>http://mg.co.za/article/2013-07-19-fhm-fires-rape-comment-writers</ref>
South Africa is a signatory of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW), which obligates states to remove discriminatory barriers from the full and free exercise of rights by women. The Convention's duty to modify the conduct of private citizens to ensure equality for women covers attitudes that include the inferiority of women and stereotyped gender roles, which arguably encompass the animus toward gay women that motivates many men to commit corrective rape.<ref name="Di" /> 66% of South Africa women said they did not report their attack because they would not be taken seriously.<ref name="Actionaid" /> Of these, 25% said they feared exposing their sexual orientation to the police and 22% said they were afraid of being abused by the police.<ref name="Actionaid" />
In August 2011, the [[Department of Justice and Constitutional Development|Department of Justice]] established a National Task Team (NTT) to address the issue of hate crimes against LGBT people.<ref>{{cite news |title=Team starts work on gay hate crimes |agency=[[South African Press Association|SAPA]]-DPA |date=10 August 2011 |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/team-starts-work-on-gay-hate-crimes-1.1115051 |newspaper=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL News]] |accessdate=15 August 2011|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6RD3RrFs8|archivedate=20 July 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref> In April 2014, then [[Minister of Justice and Constitutional Development|Minister of Justice]] [[Jeff Radebe]] launched a National Intervention Strategy for the LGBTI Sector developed by the NTT to address sex-based violence and [[gender-based violence]] against members of the community. The NTT has established a rapid response team to attend to unsolved criminal cases as a matter of urgency and produced an information pamphlet with frequently asked questions about LGBTI persons. Radebe stated that the Department of Justice acknowledged the need for a specific legal framework for hate crimes and that the matter would be subjected to public debate.<ref>{{cite web|title=National Intervention Strategy for LGBTI Sector 2014|url=http://www.justice.gov.za/vg/lgbti/2014-LGBTI-Strategy.pdf|publisher=Department of Justice and Constitutional Development|accessdate=20 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Radebe launches LGBTI violence programme|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/crime-courts/radebe-launches-lgbti-violence-programme-1.1681563#.U8vOjOOSyyg|accessdate=20 July 2014|agency=SAPA|newspaper=IOL|date=29 April 2014|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6RD3bz2dy|archivedate=20 July 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Diale|first1=Lerato|title=Plan to combat gender violence|url=http://www.thenewage.co.za/124285-1007-53-Plan_to_combat_gender_violence|accessdate=20 July 2014|work=The New Age|date=30 April 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720144529/http://www.thenewage.co.za/124285-1007-53-Plan_to_combat_gender_violence|archivedate=20 July 2014|deadurl=no}}</ref>
In March 2011, there was an article published that stated that there are about 10 new cases of corrective rape a week in Cape Town.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.irinnews.org/report/92198/south-africa-activism-makes-inroads-corrective-rape|title=Activism makes inroads on "corrective rape"|date=2011-03-15|website=IRIN|access-date=2016-05-02}}</ref> [[Cape Town|Cape Town, South Africa]] specifically has 2.5 million people and since 2011, the prevalence of Corrective Rape has only increased.
=== Uganda === {{Further information|LGBT rights in Uganda}}
Five cases in which the victims were lesbians or transgender males were reported in [[Uganda]] between June and November, 2011.<ref name="GuarUganda"/>
=== Jamaica === {{Further information|LGBT rights in Jamaica}}
Amnesty International has received reports of violence against lesbians in [[Jamaica]], including rape and other forms of sexual violence. Lesbians reportedly have been attacked on the grounds of mannish physical appearance or other visible signs of sexuality. Some reports of abduction and rape come from inner-city communities, where local non-governmental organizations have expressed concerns about high incidences of violence against women.<ref>{{cite news | last=Czyzselska | first=Jane | title=No Woman No Cry: Lesbians in Jamaica | url=http://www.gaytimes.co.uk/HotSpots/Travel-page-3-sectionid-1-articleid-357.html | newspaper=GayTimes}}</ref>
==Campaigning and activism== Child sponsorship charity [[ActionAid]] has published an article discussing corrective rape, and see ending violence against women as a pivotal part of their mission.<ref name="Actionaid" /> The group joined with 26 gay and women’s rights and community groups, to organize a campaign focused on South Africa but also aimed at the international community, to raise awareness of the issues. The campaign was dedicated to the rape and murder of two lesbian women in a Johannesburg township and called for sexual orientation to be specifically recognised as grounds for protection by police and justice systems.<ref name="Actionaid" />
Ndumie Funda, a South African Social Justice Activist, started her work to end Corrective Rape by launching a social campaign on [[Change.org]] in hopes to have the South African Government recognize hate crimes committed due to biases against sexual orientation and provide protection for victims. This particular petition ended up gathering almost 200 thousand signatures from individuals making up over 175 different countries-this forced the government to recognize this issue. The government agreed to meeting Funda and in 2014 South Africa passed its first law against hate crimes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thedp.com/article/2015/02/south-africa-ndumie-funda|title=Activist takes on mission against "corrective" rape|website=www.thedp.com|access-date=2016-05-02}}</ref>
